summary: 3D4/31 macrophages and dudleya brittonii were used as the in vitro porcine alveolar macrophages model. the cells were activated by exposure to phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA) study provides new insights and directions for further research relating to the immunity of porcine respiratory system. rapid climate changes (heat wave, fine dust, etc.) have negatively affected livestock immunity. this trend has been exacerbated by the prohibition of growth-promoting hormones and antibiotics in livestock breeding. the FAO pathway functions by converting fatty-acyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA by acetyl-CoA carboxylase alpha (ACACA) and the production of palmitic acid (most basic fatty acids found in mammals) from malonyl-CoA or acetyl-CoA by fatty acid synthase (FASN) dudleya brittonii (D. brittonii) is a succulent plant mainly found in California and Mexico. it is used for treating asthma, an inflammatory airway obstruction disease closely associated with macrophages. a small number of succulent plants have been successfully used for commercial purposes. 3103 3D4/31 macrophages were seeded in 96-well cell culture plates. after 24 h, cells were treated with DB (9 ng/mL) and/or 2 nM phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate. each absorbance was measured at 450 nm using a microplate reader. cell numbers were assessed every 24 h using a hemocytometer and 0.4% (w/v) trypan blue. images were processed with the Axio vision Rel. 4.7 (Carl Zeiss) and Photoshop CC 2018 program (Adobe Systems, San Jose, CA, USA) cells were washed with DB (9 ng/mL) and/or 2 nM PMA for 12 h. cells were then fixed and permeabilized using ice-cold ethanol at 20°C. after 30 min incubation room temperature, cells were stained with PI solution. cDNA synthesis of 3D4/31 macrophages was performed using the 2X SYBR Green PCR Master Mix. the qPCR was performed by using the StepOnePlus Real-Time PCR System. mRNA fold change was analyzed using the 2Ct method [24]. GGCTCCTCCTTCATCTCC HK2 F: CACTGCTGAAGGAAGCCATC (Hexokinase2) R: CTCTGGAGGTGTGCAGATCA (Hexokinase3) R: TTCTGCTGGAAGTCCACGAT PFKP F: CCGACGGACACAAGATGTTC (Phosphofructokinase platelet) R: TTCTCCCAAGAAGTGCCT PFKL ATCATGCTGCTAA (Very long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase) R: GCGTGGCTTATGGTGTGTG (Long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase) R: TCGCCCAGTTTCTGTGTGTGAC (Acetyl-CoA acyltransferase 1A) R: TCCTGCTTTTTTGCGTGTCT (Peroxisome proliferator-activated Statistical analysis All experiments were repeated at least three times. data are expressed as the meanstandard deviation (SD) analysis was performed by GraphPad PRISM 8 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA, USA) 3103 3D4/31 macrophages were seeded in 96-well cell culture plates. after 24 h, cells were treated with DB (900, 9, 0.09 ng/mL) and/or 2 nM phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate. each absorbance was measured at 450 nm using a microplate reader. 5105 macrophages were seeded in a 60-mm cell culture dish. cells were exposed to DB (900, 9, 0.09 ng/mL) with/without 2 nM PMA. cells were harvested and washed with phosphate buffered saline. 5105 cells 3D4/31 macrophages were seeded in a 60-mm cell culture dish. after 12 h, cells were treated with DB (9 ng/mL) and/or 2 nM PMA for 24 h. the cells were washed with PBS and fixed in 3.8% formaldehyde for 15 min. stepOnePlus Real-Time PCR System (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA) mRNA fold change was analyzed using the 2Ct method [24]. primer sequences for fatty acid synthesis, fatty acid oxidation, glycolysis, and tricarboxylic acid cycle Target genes Sequences (5′ to 3′) ruvate kinase muscle. ruvate kinase liver & red blood cells. analysis was performed by GraphPad PRISM 8 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA, USA) and Microsoft Excel (Office 365; Redmond, WA, USA) data are considered statistically significant when the p-value is 0.05. RESULTS Dudleya brittonii extract protect 3D4/31 macrophages against phorbol phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate induced cell death. the assay showed a dose-dependent decrease in viability after exposure to DB. co-treatment with DB and PMA for 24 h significantly increased the cell viability by up to 11.87%4.62% as compared to PMA treated cells. cell number (B) and phenotype (C) of 3D4/31 macrophages replaced every 24 h. survival rate of 3D4/31 macrophages dramatically decreased when activated by PMA. DB effectively prevents the PMA-induced inhibition of survival rate. exposure to DB reduces cell death in activated macrophages. results demonstrate that DB reduces cell death in activated macrophages. DB-PMA co-treatment reduced the ROS level by 23.43% 8.54%. DB, dudleya brittonii extract, phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate, ROS, reactive oxygen species, DCF-DA, dichlorofluorescein diacetate. all data represent the meanstandard deviation (n = 3); * p0.05, ** p0.01, *** p0.001. highest increase confirmed after co-treatment of PMA and DB. DB upregulates fatty acid synthesis in 3D4/31 macrophages. qPCR analysis of fatty acid synthesis related genes. PMA and DB-PMA co-treatment suggests induction of M2-like differentiation of 3D4/31 macrophages. however, there are few studies reporting the changes in lipid production of porcine AMs. however, there are few studies reporting the changes in lipid production of porcine AMs. kinase liver and red blood cells [PKLR], pyruvate kinase muscle [PKM] and increased expression of FAO genes. DB induces an M2-like metabolic change in 3D4/31 macrophages that are not yet activated. DB extract promotes the M2-like metabolic reprogramming, decreases glycolysis, and increases FAO and TCA cycle. DB extract promotes the M2-like metabolic reprogramming, decreases glycolysis, and increases FAO and TCA cycle. leya brittonii extract protect 3D4/31 macrophages against phorbol phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate induced cell death. the assay showed a dose-dependent decrease in viability after exposure to DB. co-treatment with DB and PMA for 24 h significantly increased the cell viability by up to 11.87%4.62% compared to PMA treated cells. the survival rate of 3D4/31 macrophages was dramatically decreased when activated by PMA. DB effectively prevents the PMA-induced inhibition of survival rate. exposure to DB reduces cell death in activated macrophages. DB-PMA co-treatment reduced ROS level by 23.43% 8.54%. DB has antioxidant effect on both non-activated and PMA-activated 3D4/31 macrophages. ROS levels (D), was measured via flow cytometry with DCF-DA. Activated M1 macrophage ROS plays an important role in phagocytosis. but excessive ROS production induces inflammation and apoptosis. DB has a positive effect on the lipid metabolism of 3D4/31 macrophages. DB upregulates the fatty acid synthesis in 3D4/31 macrophages. qPCR analysis of fatty acid synthesis related genes. DB-PMA co-treatment suggests induction of M2-like differentiation of 3D4/31 macrophages. however, there are few studies reporting changes in lipid production of porcine AMs. however, there are few studies reporting the changes in lipid production of porcine AMs. DB induces an M2-like metabolic change in 3D4/31 macrophages that are not yet activated. only a small number of gene expressions (ACACA, CTS) were increased. increased expression of FAO genes and increased expression of FAO genes. qPCR analysis was performed after treatment with DB (9 ng/mL) and/or PMA (2 nM) for 12 h. DB extract promotes the M2-like metabolic reprogramming, decreases glycolysis, and increases FAO and TCA cycle. DB upregulates the cell survival rate of 3D4/31 macrophages by antioxidant and fatty acid oxidation. DB reduces macrophage activation (PMA induced) induced ROS generation and cell death. AMs function even under normal conditions, even if there is no infection. survival rate-enhancing effect of DB on activated AMs may help to prevent respiratory infectious diseases by improving the respiratory immunity of livestock. steroid treatment prevents livestock diseases, and lung infections are improved by steroid sensor stimulation such as SRC3 of AMs. DB upregulates the FAS, FAO, and TCA cycle genes, as well as SRC3 mRNA expression. study confirms a new mechanism for the association of lipid metabolism and survival enhancement in the porcine AMs. it suggests administering DB could potentially improve the survival rate of AMs.
